title: Growing Through Change
description: Explore how you navigate life transitions and changes together.

questions.text: When big changes happen in our lives, I tend to...
choices: Adapt quickly and embrace the new
Need time to process and adjust
Focus on what we can control
Lean on you more than usual

therapeutic.rationale: How we respond to change reveals our coping patterns and attachment needs. Quick adapters thrive on novelty; processors need integration time; controllers seek agency; leaners need connection during uncertainty. Knowing each other's patterns helps you support each other.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different change responses can cause friction. The quick adapter may feel the processor is resistant; the processor may feel rushed. Give each other space to handle change in your own way while staying connected.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared change responses create natural synchrony during transitions. You'll naturally support each other because you understand the experience.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically respond to major changes? What do you need from your partner during transitions?

questions.text: The kind of change that challenges me most is...
choices: Unexpected or sudden changes
Changes I didn't choose
Changes that affect our relationship
Changes in routine or stability

therapeutic.rationale: Understanding what types of change are hardest helps couples prepare for and support each other through life transitions. Unexpected changes test flexibility; unchosen changes test acceptance; relationship changes test security; routine changes test adaptability.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different change sensitivities mean you may struggle with different aspects of the same transition. Be aware of what's hardest for your partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared change sensitivities mean you'll need similar support during certain types of transitions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What type of change is hardest for you? How can your partner help during those times?

questions.text: When we're going through change together, I need...
choices: Extra reassurance about us
Open conversation about what's happening
Space to process on my own first
A sense of what comes next

therapeutic.rationale: Needs during change reflect attachment and communication styles. Reassurance-seekers need security confirmation; talkers need verbal processing; space-needers need solitude first; planners need future clarity. Explicitly stating needs prevents misunderstandings.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs during change require flexibility. The space-needer may seem distant to the reassurance-seeker. Communicate your needs explicitly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched needs during change make supporting each other intuitive. You'll naturally provide what your partner wants.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you most need from your partner when life is changing? Have you told them?

questions.text: Looking back, a change that made us stronger was...
choices: A challenge we overcame together
A move or major life transition
A growth period for one of us
A difficult time we survived

therapeutic.rationale: Reflecting on past changes that strengthened the relationship builds confidence for future transitions. It creates a shared narrative of resilience and reminds couples of their capability.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different memories of strengthening changes are all valid. You may remember different aspects of the same event as most meaningful.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared memory of a strengthening change creates a powerful reference point for future challenges.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What past change made your relationship stronger? What did you learn from navigating it together?

questions.text: I believe change in a relationship...
choices: Is inevitable and can be positive
Requires intentional effort to navigate
Can bring us closer if we let it
Is something we should embrace together

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about change shape how couples approach transitions. Seeing change as inevitable normalizes it; seeing it as requiring effort honors the work; seeing it as closeness-building creates hope; embracing it together emphasizes partnership.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these beliefs support healthy change navigation. Discuss which perspective feels most true for each of you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy about change creates aligned expectations for how you'll handle life transitions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you believe about change in relationships? How does that belief serve you?
